segments.text: I'm just trying to understand why they were saying there's five sexes in humans when there's clearly two.
I say that as someone who's studied biology for a long time.
Today I sit down with Colin Wright, an evolutionary biologist and founding editor of Reality's Last Stand.
His cartoon about his sense of alienation from the left went viral after it was retweeted by Elon Musk.
So it's not that the kids are even confused about whether they're trans or literally be told if you're gender nonconforming, then you're trans.
Maybe we can give this person puberty blockers, which is sort of a gateway to
acoustics hormones and surgeries and things like that.
He explains why gender ideology is so damaging to society and how he sees universities using diversity, equity and inclusion, DEI, to determine hiring, promotions and tenure.
And at Berkeley and increasingly at more universities, they're using these DEI statements as a first filter.
You know, I view them as political litmus test because there is only one way to write these things.
This is American Thought Leaders and I'm Jan Yeh Kelly.
Colin Wright, it's such a pleasure to have you on American Thought Leaders.
Thank you for having me. This is fantastic.
I agree. I've wanted to talk to you for a while and we have this perfect opportunity with Elon Musk
having tweeted this graphic, very, very interesting graphic.
And so how did this graphic come about?
It's been such a bizarre week after that happened.
Yeah.

You know, this is a cartoon that I just created one night in my pajamas and it sort of just was meant to have me just sort out my own feelings of being sort of alienated from, I guess, the political left on a lot of issues that I felt were very like core for me.
Issues like freedom of speech that normally on the left were viewed as sort of these sacrosanct value in order to speak truth to people.
And so the power is being increasingly viewed as being, you know, with suspicion you see it published in articles with scare quotes like quote unquote free speech.
And it's even being accused of being dangerous to democracy and minorities.
Other issues such as, you know, the old value of treating people and judging people by the content of their character instead of by the color of their skin.
And recently these new ideas ushered in sort of this identity politics, these equity initiatives that are basing rights on group interest instead of individual rights.
And then on a topic that's sort of closest to me is the whole women's rights issue where we've now seen this sort of shift on the left of what a woman even is.
Is it even definable? Is it related to biology?
And so I had come from a background in evolutionary biology where I saw people sort of making these weird claims about sex and about gender and are they the same or are they different.
And when I started pushing back against the stuff, you know, using scientific arguments, I was just called all these crazy names.
And so on like on all these topics where I previously identified with, you know, these are core, I just no longer really see them best represented on the political left.

And it's made me and I think a lot of others and if you identify with that cartoon, maybe feeling sort of politically homeless in a certain way or at least you don't see those values on the left anymore.
So, you know, I'm a lifelong Democrat and this cartoon represents those core values but not necessarily every axis, but at least on these core values that I felt that caused me to vote Democrat.
That's what this cartoon really represents for me.
And you notice, you know, these some of these subtle changes but I think it was really in your work that you first started just kind of asking yourself, what am I doing?
And so tell me about that.
That was a very slow burn and I didn't even notice, really noticed the change until I had changed so much.
You know, I started out going, you know, as an undergrad, wanted to become a professor studying evolutionary biology.
You know, I went and got into graduate school, started a lab, you start meeting other faculty and things like that.
You might, you know, if you had some pictures from undergrad, a view at a party or something, maybe you'll take those off your timeline or something.
And then it was other things like, oh, what pages was I liking on those things?
Maybe, you know, this is maybe a controversial thing and I just want to make sure because it's public and I've had some advisors were following me on Facebook.
And it was just really sort of incremental over time until I got to the point where I'm at Penn State and I'm doing my postdoctoral fellowship there.
And I'm just like closing down every single bit of my social media.
What pages am I liking? Anything? I don't like any pages because I'm not sure which ones are going to be okay to talk about.
I started seeing these articles being published saying that there's, you know, five sexes and things like that.
And I would just make an initial question, like, what do they mean by this?
And it was just immediately attacked.
And I just slowly realized looking back, like, my initial reasons for going into academia were so I could ask these types of questions.
I could ask any questions.
I thought academia was the place where you ask questions and you receive feedback from people who aren't going to attack you the person.
But they're going to attack the idea.
And everyone realizes that we're all playing the truth game and trying to just find out what's truth.
But I wasn't getting that. I wasn't getting people, you know, just asking me questions back and why do you think that way?
You know, here's this evidence. Here's that.
It was just you're being transphobic. You're a bigot. This is rooted in white supremacy.
All this type of stuff. And I'm just trying to understand why they're saying there's five sexes and humans when there's clearly two.
Because this is mean. I say that as someone who's studied biology for a long time.
So yeah, so it was just this slow shift.
I think it's just because each day you're not changing very much.
You're not self-sensoring a whole lot each day. It's little by little until I got to the point where I realized how I completely muzzled.
I made myself.
So there's is there some specific moment where you made a decision to shift gears?
There was there was a series of events. So there was the the Sokel squared hoax that James Lindsay,
home pluck rose Peter Bogosian where they had sort of they put these, I guess, hoax papers.
Although they were legitimate papers they put in. You know, they a lot of them were just using the same arguments they would and they weren't some weren't based on data.
So they they got these into some journals that dealt with like gender.
And I had always already been questioning of this whole like gender ideology.
What do people mean when they say they identify as a man or a woman as opposed to just being a man or a woman.
And then we had the Scientific American. They published an article that was called like the sex spectrum.
It was this beautiful diagram that just showed male and female on each side.
Then they had like this big spectrum in between and it was saying, you know, there's no such thing as male or female.
We're all just sort of clouds of maleness and femaleness and you can reside anywhere on the spectrum.
And then there was an article in Nature. I think it was called Sex Redefined and the subtitle was the idea of two sexes is now viewed as overly simplistic.
And then, you know, there were just these terrible arguments looking at chromosomes and talking about hormones.
And, you know, these things don't make male or female. They're just, you know, they're associated with that.
And these were so easily debunked and to see them in such like these prestigious platforms.
I mean, Scientific American is not a journal, but it's a popular trusted scientific outlet anyway.
But then Nature, this is like the most prestigious journal in the entire world.
And when I saw that it was in Nature, yeah, I couldn't really stay quiet anymore.
I literally asked myself what would Christopher Hitchens do because I knew this would potentially be career suicide.
Both my advisors, well, my advisor and my mentor both told me not to publish my initial article on Quillit on this.

But I just realized like I studied animal personality, social behavior, and I just couldn't deal with the fact that I'd be potentially teaching my work on collective behavior and social spiders or WASP personalities.
When half my class might not even know what a male and female is or might not even be convinced that those are even real biological categories.
I just couldn't care about the minutiae when the big picture was seeming to be distorted behind me.
Fascinating. And so, yeah, so you did publish in Quillit. So that was actually your, that was the moment where you really went public with your views, I guess.
Is that right? Yeah.
And so what happened with this Quillit article subsequent to that?
Yeah, it went super viral. And I was reading like every comment on Twitter.
And most people, because the article basically said, you know, there's, it was called the New Evolution Deniers.
And it talked about how in the past it had been sort of the attacks to evolution had been from the right, from evangelicals, you know, doing creationism or intelligent design.
But now we have this new strain of people who were denying evolution, you know, of sex differences and stuff.
But unlike the previous attacks that were coming from outside the academy from evangelicals, because they don't really have a big presence in the evolutionary biology community, if you can imagine.
But now being in the academy, these attacks are coming from within.
And so they're much more difficult to root out. And they had sort of elicited this, this immune response to me when I was sort of trying to push back against these things.
So I tried to address that, that major problem and the nuances of, you know, inside the academy versus outside and why this is causing a lot of people to sort of self censor.
A lot of the responses to it were this, you know, saying that I was conflating sex and gender.
Because in the past we were, people were asked, at least if you were on the left to say that, you know, you're sex, male or female, that's like the biology.
But you're gender, and then they use the words man and woman. That was sort of more an identity.
And this is something that a lot of people were okay with. They're like, okay, as long as, and I was okay with it too at the time.
I was like, okay, well, as long as there's a wall between identity and biology, then like, okay, I can, I can meet you halfway.
And then these articles, these were just like completely obliterating that wall between them.
People were identifying as sex is saying that it's a social construct, all this stuff.
That's what the article pointed out. And people were just really, they didn't believe me when I said people were denying that sex was a little bit different.
They were denying that sex is real. And I actually occasionally go back to read those comments because it's just kind of like interesting to see what people thought then because now people get it.
Now it's the cats out of the bag and they know that people really are saying that male and female aren't even these real natural categories anymore.
But my piece was one of the first to really spell that out. I think in great detail.
And what year was this? It was 2018.
It's incredible. Four years how things have shifted.
There's people who were talking about it before me, but I think my article at least went the most viral on it.
Now, what about your mentor, your supervisor, your coworkers people on people presumably on scientific papers with you, what happened there?
So I have some mentors that agree with me. And a lot of them too, that were closest to me, they told me when I sent them the essay first, if I'm to look at it, is this correct?
And their response was, everything in this is perfectly fine and true, but you can't publish it because it would just sink your career completely.
And that really took me back because again, as I mentioned, this is why my science, if I can't publish something that's true.
And that's when I did the whole, what would Christopher Hitchens do?
Well, he would just say screw you and he'd publish it and deal with the consequences.
So that's eventually what I ended up doing.
So I still have some mentors that support me behind the scenes.
They won't acknowledge it publicly. I used to give talks to their university.

I'm no longer invited to give those talks, even though they don't have a problem with me, but they just think that if we get protested, they were the ones who invited me, who caused a lot of trouble for them.
And I have some colleagues that have just outright denounced me on social media.
They think I've just turned into, I don't know, close to the devil himself, it seems by looking at how they talk about me on social media.
But again, I've always just maintained that sex is real and it's important in some context.
And I'm open to discussing the issues with anyone who wants to have the conversation.
So that doesn't seem too devilish to me.
For the record, right?
It does seem amazing that we have to kind of spell this out, but
why is it not a spectrum?
Why is it polar?

Yeah, because when you look at what a male and female are, they're defined by the reproductive anatomy that is developed for the production of either small or large gamete, sex cells, either sperm or egg.
Those reproductive systems, they don't really come in and have, most people at birth are identifiably male or female, 99.98% of the time.
Some could be intersex.

I leave it open to have some individuals be kind of sexually ambiguous, but that doesn't mean they're a third sex because there's not a third type of sex cell that they're anatomy is organized around to produce.
There's only males and females and then intersex people, which most of those conditions are actually distinctly male or female intersex conditions.
But just because you might be sort of sexually ambiguous, this doesn't mean there's more than two sexes.
People usually conflate my claim that sex is binary with the claim that everyone who exists is either male or female.
But what I'm really saying is there's only two sexes and some, maybe some people are sexually ambiguous, but they're still not a third sex, if that makes any sense.
When I say the word binary, I'm usually talking about composed of two parts like a binary star system or a binary compound, for instance.
Not like computer code where all you have are ones and zeros, but sex is primarily composed of just two parts.
And most everyone is either 100% male or 100% female, much like you flip a coin.
Just because there's an edge on the coin doesn't mean that heads and tails come in percentages or that they are social constructs.
Yeah, and that doesn't have anything to do with whether they're more masculine or feminine in their behavior or their thinking or so forth.
That's exactly the corollary, I guess, to what you're saying.
Yeah, well, so there's a couple ways people attack this, attack biological sex.
One is the whole sex is a spectrum and they'll use intersex people as this like middle ground.
And if there's a middle category, that means the other two categories don't exist, it's a spectrum.
So I just sort of described to you like why that's not the case.
And then there's this other attack where they use what are called secondary sex characteristics.
So these are the characteristics that your body undergoes during puberty.
Like women will get breasts, men will get a lot taller, their jaws jawline, they'll get facial hair.
You know, the sex differences that we commonly associate with males and females in everyday basis,
but they don't really define what you are as a male or female.
They're influenced by a fewer male or female and the types of hormones that your gonads are producing.
And people will use these secondary sex characteristics to say that sex is a spectrum
because on any one of these characteristics, you know, some males have a breast development,
some women have square jaws in their tall, some women have facial hair, like they just, some do.
There's a lot of variation out there.
And so you can see that there's like these overlap in the types of traits that males and females have.
And they use that to sort of argue that this is a spectrum of body shapes.
And while it might be a spectrum of, you know, body shapes with any respect to any of these little traits here,
again, these are secondary sex characteristics.
They don't define what it means to be your sex. They're just associated with it.
And okay, and while we're on it, you know, but why is this important?
Why is it important? You know, I think I saw you once say, this is the hill I'm going to die on.
You know, and that's like, why should it be a hill to die on?
Well, I just think it's such a fundamental part of our biology.
This is why I was, you know, in the early 2010s, I was arguing with a lot of people about whether or not it was evolution
versus intelligent design and creationism.
Because if you're denying, I think, evolution, I think you're going to get a lot of things wrong about human behavior
and certain contexts. And, you know, there's just a lot that follows from denying really fundamental aspects of our biology.
And I think the same thing accounts for biological sex.
I mean, there's so many different, you know, such a fundamental aspect of our biology and of our species.
And the evolved differences, there are between males and females, not just in their bodies, but in their, you know, their behaviors on average.
And if you're going to deny that exists, then you can't really, you know, all the studies that we're going to do on meeting interactions,
evolutionary psychology, this stuff goes out the window. You just can't make sense of so many human interactions
if you're denying, like, these fundamental biological aspects. And then on another level, just because we are a sexually dimorphic species,
in some contexts, paying attention to the sex of an individual matters.
For instance, in sports, you know, males go through puberty where we have this growth spurt.
Testosterone surges through our bodies, we get much stronger. This doesn't happen to females.
And so it makes sense to, like, segregate sports by sex because, you know, they don't have the benefits of going through this puberty that makes them,
makes males bigger, faster, and stronger in every single athletic measure.
I don't think sex should matter in all cases. It's really only a very small number of contexts, such as sports.
You know, what prison you might go to given the different rates of violence between males and females and sexual violence and things like that.
It's really only in this very small number of contexts where it matters. Like, I don't think sex should matter for getting hired if you're going to get a promotion.
There's so many things that it doesn't matter and it shouldn't matter for, but on some it really does.
And this is where I've just been trying to maintain, you know, this distinction.
So what has your reaction been to, you know, these sports and how they have changed over, like, the acceleration, I guess, in the change over the last few years?
Now, I was actually at the event at Georgia Tech where Leah Thomas, who's a biological male who identifies as a female, won the women's 500-yard freestyle.
I see it as sort of a proof that an ideology is just completely insane.
Like, if you're an engineer and you're making bridges and you're a really bad engineer, like, your bridge is going to shatter in front of you.
You'll see your bridges. They're not going to withstand heavy trucks going over them.
And I kind of, it's more difficult to see, like, an immediate consequence of your bad ideas that you might have about human nature.
Sometimes they're not so apparent as, like, a collapsing bridge.
But if you're denying that biological sex is real, I see that the fact that we have a male competing in a female sport who's, like, now the women's national division 1 champion,
to me that's, like, the ideological equivalent of, like, a bridge collapsing and it shows the absurdity of an ideology.
It really is just, like, the ultimate representation of why this ideology is completely wrong.

The notion that we even need to segregate sports by an identity instead of sex, and this is what these people are claiming, that sports are segregated by your gender identity instead of your biological sex.
But there's nothing about a gender identity that makes you better or worse at sports.
It would be like segregating sports by a political party or something like that.
So it's just completely arbitrary, but people are pretending that this is what it's always been. It's always referred to.
So, I mean, I call my website, like, reality's last stand, just because, to me, like, this is the low-hanging fruit of getting something right.

Like, it's really easy. Like, even a child knows that male and female are different, and this matters in certain contexts, and, you know, we have a lot of people saying to follow the science who are saying that males and females don't exist.
And this is, as you mentioned, the hill that I've chosen to die on.
You know, I'm sure many people have made this comparison to you, but it's the, you know, the emperor has no clothes, the story, right?
So you're the kid here, right, basically saying, hey, why is it so few people? Like, how many people in your school, how many people in your profession are talking about this?

Almost no one, really. I can't think of anyone in my, who was a colleague with me, who would at least publicly say the stuff that I say on Twitter and in my essays about male and female not being social constructs about the need to certain, you know, segregate certain areas,

and then I have a couple of different aspects that make sense. I know some of my colleagues who just don't say it because they don't agree with it, but they're not saying it because they think it would be, you know, career suicide form.

And then there's a healthy bunch that I think actually somehow believe it, but I've also seen the trajectory of them going from a place where they would have agreed with me, and I have seen them tweet about these things, or we've had conversations before.
And I've seen them sort of slide over the last few years into just a full embrace of this whole sex denialism that I'm seeing.
So it's, there's almost no one talking about this. I've had some journal editors reach out to me who wanted me to write the scientific paper about why sex is in the spectrum.
And I'm not even the world expert on this. Like, I studied bugs. I studied insect behavior.
But it's really interesting that they can't find anyone who is in academia who would actually be an expert on sex development and all these things.

They can't find them to write the articles that they want to be written to debunk a lot of the stuff. So they have to find like the exiled spider biologists to write these things because there's nothing they can take away from me.
You know, I'm not going up for tenure. I'm not going to be in the field trying to collaborate with people. So I have nothing to lose.
So that's the weird situation we find ourselves in now with scientific publishing.
And so, well, there's Brett Weinstein, of course, right? That is, I think, probably would agree with you.
Yeah, him and his wife Heather Heing, they both, they talk about this fairly frequently. Yeah, they would definitely agree.
This is something everyone agrees with. Like, this isn't a controversial statement. It's, I'm always in this weird space where people think it's a controversial thing.
But me and Brett and Heather, we're not saying things that most, the vast majority of scientists weren't saying five years ago.
And the only reason they're not saying it now is because of this sort of this cultural social shift.
So we're just middle of the road biologist from 2015.
Yeah. Because there's a certain level of cognitive dissonance like you have to deal with, presumably.
You know, I think it was said well by Peter Rogosian recently. He said, you know, in the past, you would have a lot of intellectuals and scientists.
And we're always sort of making caveats and claiming, you know, making sure that we're not saying things that we don't know are true.
But now we're sort of in this position where a lot of academics are pretending not to know things they know,
rather than pretending to know things that they don't know. It's just the opposite.
Like people know what males and females are, but they have to sort of portray ignorance on some of these topics in order to, like, still get invited to the cocktail parties or something.
Well, it actually reminds me of something you told me about, also offline, which was just this, there was this point at which you know, critical race theory was kind of entering the academy.
And you were actually studying to how to write your diversity, equity and inclusion statements for applications and things like this.
Can you tell me a little bit about this? There's this kind of shift, right? And what was required to get the next position or apply and so forth?
And previously, if you're applying to a professor job, you'd have your CV that you attach.
We send them, of course, as all your publications and everywhere you've worked before, all the talks you've given.
You'd send them a research statement that talks about all the research you've done before and sort of what you plan to do in the first five years at this university when you're going for tenure.
It needs to be this extraordinarily detailed document. I'm going to have this many students doing this.
I'm going to get a postdoc that's going to work on these projects, ABC, A1, A2, all that stuff.
And then sometimes they'd have sort of another, like it may be a teaching statement, what's your teaching philosophy?
These were usually what you'd have to submit. They recently then started adding something called like a DEI or Diversity, Equity and Inclusion statement.
And I think initially a lot of these things were just pledging that you're not going to discriminate on based on certain traits.

But then they started really taking a real ideological slant where they had to be written in a certain way and they would have workshops that I had to go to where they told you exactly what you needed to write.
You need to concentrate on the disparity. You don't see as many minorities in academia and STEM because of all the systemic barriers.
But it was only looked through one very clear left-wing lens of why these disparities might exist.
I would probably agree with some of them, but not all of them. But I just remember not agreeing with a lot of these things.
And I was being asked to even list all the racial and sexual minorities that I had ever mentored.
And I had mentored people who were gay and people who were racial minorities, but it was never because they were black or because they were gay or anything.
I just picked the person who I thought was the most enthusiastic and who would do the best job.
And so it just felt like actually listing these people on this document of just like, oh, there is this person. They were gay. There was this person. They were black.
This person was from Vietnam. It just felt like this total dehumanizing experience.
Like I'm taking the complexity of all these individuals that I knew well because I would work with a whole summer for these people.
My really became good friends. And I'm just sort of flattening them all into this one label and like pretending and then using them to sort of stand on top of and say, hire me.
That's sort of how it would have felt like I was doing. I just felt really uncomfortable.

And then I didn't understand why I had to fill this out along with theoretical physicists. I mean, they have to do these things too to get a job as a physicist or a microbiologist or in my case, an evolutionary biologist or an ecologist.
It seemed to have nothing to do with the job itself. And then some of the DEI statements would even go further.
And they would ask, how does your research further DEI?
You know, when I studied, again, the social behavior of insects and arachnids, there was nothing out that I'm doing that my research.
My research is not about human increasing diversity. It's about the behavior of bugs.
And so some of these were just impossible to write. And then I would ask, why am I trying to, why am I being asked to write these in the first place to get a job as a professor?
So did you write any? Can I ask you?
I did.
Yeah.
So I wrote one and it was focused on community colleges because I went to community college myself. I thought it was a great experience.
And partially because of the diversity that was at a community college, you have had classes where someone sitting next to was 75 years old.
They were just going back there because they enjoyed learning stuff. They would just take a class on, I think they were taking an Italian class when I was taking my foreign language class.
There were people who were from the military. There's a lot of single moms. There's so much like actual diversity that you don't get in most universities.

But one thing about, you know, a STEM major like myself is if you start out going to a community college, you don't have the opportunity to do the hands-on research because they don't have the funding, the scientists there.
They're just teachers. They don't run their own labs or anything.

And so my DEI statement was about how I was at Penn State at the time, how I want to bring people from the community colleges, these STEM majors in there because there are a lot of underrepresented minorities in these groups and bring them into Penn State, have them participate alongside Penn State students
just so they can have that experience. They can help build their CVs. I thought that was a really good diversity statement.
And one that I would agree with, one that I thought was pretty noble, I'd sent it out to some people who were on these diversity committees just to check it out, like how was it going to do.
And they just straight up told me that this is not going to fly. At least the person I sent it to was at a Canadian university.
And they told me that this wouldn't fly at any Canadian. You need to talk about equity, you need to talk about the disparities in certain groups in a very structured way.
You can even look at the rubric that UC Berkeley has when they evaluate their candidates.
And at Berkeley, increasingly at more universities, they're using these DEI statements as a first filter.
So before you send your CV, it would go straight to the department and the department had to look at it. So these are actual scientists looking at it.
Now your application has to pass through the HR department when they're looking first at the DEI statement.
So if you score below a 4 out of 6 or something, they don't even pass your CV on to the department.
And so this is what you're dealing with at places at least like Berkeley, and I'm sure that's been adopted at many other places.
So these are what some people have called the diversity commissars, I guess, that are saying that these statements are passing through.
Yeah, they're extremely common now. Maybe about a third of the universities I applied to before had them.
And I think probably, you know, I left academia right when the whole George Floyd stuff was going on right before actually.
And there was a massive push to have these. I still get the emails from the University of California, Santa Barbara where I finished my PhD.

And immediately after that, the students wrote these big, you know, one big email signed by just about everyone they could find saying that they wanted to adopt Berkeley's DEI statements as the first filter.
And also use these DEI statements and your DEI track record for going on to get tenure and additional promotions after that.
So at every step of the pipeline, and I even know kids applying to just to an undergrad, they have to write these two and to apply to grad school, they need to do it.
And to apply to postdocs, they do it. And then postdocs applying to professorships need to do it.
And then as you try to rise the ranks and as a professor, it's all DEI all the way through.
So the pipeline is just peppered with these hurdles basically.
I view them as political litmus test because there is only one way to write these things.
And you have to just sort of slide into that way of speaking about these things that you commonly hear.
I mean, it's all boilerplate. If you've read it once, you've read it a million times.
So basically you're calling it a political litmus test.
I.E. there's just, you know, you give me the correct answer, you can pass go, so to speak.
Yeah, because it's usually illegal to ask directly, you know, what your races or things like that.
Like in California they use these DEI statements because they explicitly can't hire students or hire anyone based on race.
So they encourage people to do these DEI statements and they encourage them to talk about their experience, you know, with oppression and things like that.
And so from these statements, you can sort of glean racial information off these things in order to sort of hire whoever you want to hire.
So this is sort of a way to just, you know, work around one for their, you know, the sort of equity race-based hiring that they want to do.
And then on top of that, there's like the political litmus test where, you know, you have to speak in terms of equity and group disparity and systemic racism and all that stuff.
You mentioned to me that you felt like some of your coworkers or peers or co-authors were basically told they kind of have to denounce you.
So tell me about this.
I had one colleague who, you know, in the past we had agreed on lots of stuff.
And this is someone that I knew would have disagreed with this statement, trans women are biological women because they publicly said it was as ridiculous as believing in a flat earth, for instance.
And then they got a job at university and then very soon after they had pronouns go up on their bio and on their email signature.
And then I'm getting a phone call from this person or text anyway.
And this is someone that I had collaborated with.
I had co-authored papers on spiders and ants and things with.
And this person said that their colleagues are seeing that we've co-authored papers.
